displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: that much of a difference. So… Family Member: Is that the only lymph node involved? Doctor: That’s visible right now. Family Member: Oh, okay. So that’s the same one that’s been there? Doctor: Previously, before we started, I think there were more than one that we were seeing. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

displayed_text: Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent. Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll request, I don't know if its available, but I hope it is; if it’s eight a.m., it will be earlier. Patient: That will be fine. Doctor: So that will be for the appointment itself. So we’ll sign that. And then the next step will be to order the PSA and the testosterone the week before Patient: Could you also include the um, my diabetes AC. Doctor: The A1C. Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor. Doctor: Okay, so a week before would be the week of January eighth. I’m just going to click on that day and I’ll click on the boxes approximate, so it will be any day of the week of January eighth – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - and then I’ll click on LabCorp. Patient: Uh hum, can you do multiple orders or do just have to be one order. Doctor: Each one is separate, so you can have three different pieces of paper printed out. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Hum. Doctor: That wasn’t big before, what we’ve got there. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: So we’re going to meet again after so we all describe the tests together so that you know what it is like. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change. Doctor: Exactly. No. You’re great. You had the last shot June sixth. You’re fine with that. So we’re going to extend it a week or two. Patient: Going to the bathroom. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine. Patient: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good. Patient: I’m going to eat right now. Doctor: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch?

Patient: Yeah… Doctor: And it can help with any reactions that uh from the chemo too. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So okay. (whispering inaudibly to herself) Patient: No. Doctor: I’ll send it right here? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay.

Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just….

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Same. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we appreciate… Healthcare Professional: But you can always call me too… (laughs) Doctor: Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: I’ll get your time too. Doctor: I’ll leave you guys too. I just wanted to come in and join the party for a minute. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Great. Doctor: But I know there’s more to be discussed. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So. Doctor: Exactly. So with your permission we’d like to have S____ - Patient: Mmm. Doctor: - the research nurse come talk to you about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you know… Patient: Go from there? Doctor: Yeah. We’re still very early on in the process so. Patient: Yeah, that’s fine. I’d just as soon they not come back. Doctor: Yeah and you’re not obligated… Patient: And my wife’s gone through radiation – Doctor: Sure.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial.

Family Member 2: Right, right. Doctor: I mean then I think we should sort of say I don’t care what the PSA is doing but you’re doing great and the scans are looking fine. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We just stay the course. Questions? Family Member: I just have one question. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: So from part one to part two the trial that he was on, Doctor: Mm Hmm Family Member: was there any statistics showing promise from part one to part two or was it…? Doctor: In this particular one? These pills that he’s on? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: The part two hasn’t started yet. So right now he’s is on the phase one but we know what dose to give him so… Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So in other words invisible and resistant to hormone therapy, and then we basically do the screening procedures and if you pass the screening then we enroll you in the trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But again, I didn’t want to go into a huge amount of detail because it’s a little bit premature. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it would require also that you go back on the Lupron, which I’m not sure that you would want to do that. So just Patient: Yeah, but if needs be, we can do it, we can do it. There’s another drug that we were on, too, besides Lupron. Doctor: It’s called Zytiga, also known as Abiraterone. Patient: It’s Zytiga. Right. Zytiga. Doctor: And one of the things that you and I have discussed before, and that this might be true especially if you don’t participate in the trial, would be you know could we start the Zytiga without the Lupron. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, in other words, could we have your oral therapy with the absence of or without the Lupron?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: --taking a break for a longer time or- Family Member: He needs a break. Doctor: --whatever. Patient: 'Cause that break really was nice, it worked out well the way it--I mean-- Doctor: I think your last time you really looked, uh, tired out. Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean, I was surviving--I was able to get by with work and stuff, it was-- Family Member: You got really--you were really, really tired. Doctor: I may just adjust you today because if we can keep that eye and, you know, everything else from getting worse-- Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And then, you have your PSA which is thirteen down to four point nine at your lowest, and back up to ten. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm.
